ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a higher level of comfort with speaking, reading, writing, and understanding Japanese. We learned a lot of grammar structures that are actually useful, and we learned lots of common phrases and conversational situations that frequently come up in Japan. Some elements of Japanese culture make a lot more sense after having learned about the ways the language functions.
a great introduction to basic japanese!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: constant work makes for constant improvement! very well taught, and the practice conversations are fun so the class has a good time. It might help to have more speaking practice for homework/outside of class rather than worksheets, which are only sometimes helpful.
just because of the format of the course, it was sometimes weaker at writing & conversational speaking; language table was a good supplement for that!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're really dedicated to taking Japanese (whether for fun or for the sake of learning a new language) then absolutely. But you have to want it!
of course! japanese was a blast and i had a lot of fun and learned a lot.
